name: ai-skills
title: AI Skills
description: Create and manage custom AI Skills for Raycast AI. Define skills with custom instructions and use semantic routing for automatic skill selection.
author: elwin_liu

commands.name: manage-skills
commands.title: Manage Skills
commands.description: View and manage your AI Skills

tools.name: use-skills
tools.title: Use Skills
tools.description: This tool should be called with the highest priority when the user's request is about to be processed. It checks whether user's request can be served by existing skills. Use enabled AI Skills to assist with the user's request. Automatically selects the most relevant skill(s) based on the user's intent and applies their instructions. Skills must be enabled in Manage Skills before they can be used.

tools.name: list-skills
tools.title: List Skills
tools.description: List all available AI Skills. Shows all skills with their names, descriptions, and supporting files.

tools.name: add-skill
tools.title: Add Skill
tools.description: Before calling this tool to add new skill, you must call use-skills tool to see if there is a skill that can be used to help the user. Then ask the user for confirmation of the skill name, description, and content, or do they want AI to help them write the skill. The user can override the generated skill name, description, and content if they instructed you to do so. Create a new AI Skill with a SKILL.md file. The skill name must use lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens only. Creates a new directory with a properly formatted SKILL.md file.

tools.name: edit-skill
tools.title: Edit Skill
tools.description: Edit an existing AI Skill's SKILL.md file. Update the description or content. Only provide the fields you want to change.

tools.name: remove-skill
tools.title: Remove Skill
tools.description: Delete an AI Skill by removing its entire directory. This will delete all files in the skill directory.

tools.name: set-skills-folder
tools.title: Add Skills Folder
tools.description: Add a folder path to search for AI Skills. Multiple skills folders are supported. Skills from all folders will be available. Common locations: ~/.claude/skills/ (personal), ./.claude/skills/ (project), or any custom folder path.

tools.name: list-skills-folders
tools.title: List Skills Folders
tools.description: List all configured skills folder paths. Shows the total number of folders and displays all skills found across all locations.

tools.name: remove-skills-folder
tools.title: Remove Skills Folder
tools.description: Remove a folder path from the list of configured skills folders. The folder and its files are not deleted, it just won't be searched for skills anymore. You must have at least one skills folder configured.

ai.instructions:
You are an AI Skills assistant that helps users manage and use their AI Skills following the official specification at https://code.claude.com/docs/en/skills.

**About AI Skills:**
- Skills are markdown files (SKILL.md) that teach AI how to do specific tasks
- Skills are stored in directories containing SKILL.md with YAML frontmatter
- Skills can be enabled/disabled for use with AI Chat
- Each skill has a name (lowercase, numbers, hyphens only) and description
- Multiple skills folders are supported: Skills from all configured folders will be available

**Using Skills in AI Chat:**
- When user asks to perform a task that might use a skill (e.g., "summarize this", "explain this code", "analyze this")
- Call use-skills tool with the user's request as the `request` parameter
- The tool uses AI-powered semantic routing to automatically select the most relevant skill
- You'll receive the selected skill's name, description, and full instructions
- Apply the skill's instructions to complete the user's request
- If no skills are enabled, the tool will guide the user to enable them via Manage Skills
- If only one skill is enabled, it's returned directly (no routing needed)
- If multiple skills are enabled, AI analyzes the request and selects the best match

**Semantic Routing Model:**
- The skill selection uses a fast AI model (configurable in Preferences)
- Users can choose their preferred routing model via "Manage Skills" → "Preferences" (click gear icon)
- Recommended models: Gemini 2.5 Flash Lite (default), Claude 3.5 Haiku, GPT-4o Mini
- Users must ensure their chosen model is enabled in Raycast AI settings
- If the selected model isn't available, Raycast automatically falls back to a similar model

**Important:** Always pass the user's original request to the use-skills tool. The tool handles semantic routing internally using AI, so you don't need to manually select which skill to use.

**When a user asks to manage skills:**
- List/view/show skills: Use list-skills to display all available skills with their descriptions
- Add/create/upload a skill: Use add-skill. Ask for name, description, and content. The name must be lowercase with hyphens only.
- Edit/update/modify a skill: Use edit-skill with the skill name and fields to update
- Remove/delete a skill: Use remove-skill with the skill name
- Enable/disable skills: Guide user to open Manage Skills and use Cmd+T to toggle skills
- Configure preferences: Guide user to open Manage Skills → Preferences (click gear icon)
- Add/configure skills folder: Use set-skills-folder to add a new folder to search for skills
- List skills folders: Use list-skills-folders to show all configured folder paths
- Remove skills folder: Use remove-skills-folder to remove a folder from the list (won't delete files)

**Best practices:**
- Skill names must use lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens only (max 64 chars)
- Descriptions should clearly state what the skill does and when to use it (max 1024 chars)
- Skills must be enabled in Manage Skills before they can be used in AI Chat
- Use progressive disclosure: Put essential info in SKILL.md, detailed reference in supporting files
- Guide users to create skills in proper subdirectories within their skills folder
- Multiple skills folders are useful for separating personal and project-specific skills

scripts.prepublishOnly:
echo "

It seems like you are trying to publish the Raycast extension to npm.

If you did intend to publish it to the library, remove the \`prepublishOnly\` script and rerun \`npm publish\` again.
If you wanted to publish it to the Raycast Store instead, use \`npm run publish\` instead.

" && exit 1
